messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:55): 0c25ae3066f1b9f7890ceff405fdcab1: Okay, thanks
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:55): I think I might have actually run into the same problem in the past in a totally different context, since the bug looks familiar
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:57): But I'm perfectly happy to blame Gecko for violating my expectations, regardless of what specs say, particularly if other browsers do what I want :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:14): (In this case I don't actually need border-collapse at all, so I can just remove it and it's all fine)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:24): zcorpan: no, it should look with every source, that way it starts getting one as soon as there is a good one
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (19:28): http://www.jroller.com/tedgoddard/entry/websocket_is_neither_web_nor

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:35): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I have some issues with your disposition-of-comments2html.py script, which I borrowed from XBL2. It doesn't seem to work the way I expected it would.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:35): see http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/selectors-api/disposition-of-comments.txt and http://dev.w3.org/2006/webapi/selectors-api/disposition-of-comments.html
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:35): it seems it totally ignored the summary field and used the subject line from the email as the heading instead.
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:35): fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98: there seem to be some technical inaccuracies in that post
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:37): fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98: but it does raise two interesting questions about IANA ports and WebSocket connection limits
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: when would it be appropriate for IANA to be consulted regarding ws:// port 81 and wss:// port 815 ?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:40): 7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7, when the web sockets section is relatively stable
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:42): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: are the default port numbers for ws:// and wss:// schemes not yet considered stable?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:46): are there browser vendors looking at implementing really soon?
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:48): presumably this IANA request would be one of the last steps to stabilize the WebSocket section before browser vendors would provide an implementation

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:49): it would need to be done before any release version was shipped with support for web sockets. But browsers could proceed with experimental versions before it was finalised and provide feedback
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:49): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yes, that is as designed (by summaries sucked)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:50): s/by/my/
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:50): oh. Is there another field that I can use that will be output by the script?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:50): no idea
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (19:50): or will I have to modify the script to output the summaries myself?
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:50): what is the proposed relationship between WebSocket connection limits and regular HTTP connection limits in the browser?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:50): i didn't even remember the script existed until 2 minutes ago

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:51): my impression was that there was no IANA consultation process, just a registration process, and I do not want to register anything until we know we're sure we're doing it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:51): same with the headers, mime types, etc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:51): about the only thing html5 doesn't need registering is a new top-level mime hierarchy
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:51): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: sounds like exactly the right strategy
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:52): (we're even talking about registering new registries!)
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:52): what is the proposed relationship between WebSocket connection limits and regular HTTP connection limits in the browser?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (19:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I'm sure someone will come up with a top-level MIME hierarchy for HTML 5 soon
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: We were discussing unknown as top-level, remember?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:53): 7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7: i don't think anything is proposed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:53): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: oh jeez, you're right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:53): we're EVEN considering registering a top-level mime hierarchy
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:53): what a jip
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:53): this is ridiculous
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:54): http headers, ports, schemes, mime types, mime hierarchies, registries
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:54): anything else?
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (19:55): want more stuff to consider adding for the sake of registering?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:55): lord no
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:55): just making sure i know the whole list

7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:56): given that a WebSocket connection cannot be reused, it seems appropriate to specify connection limits independent from HTTP, to avoid WebSocket taking up all the HTTP connections
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (19:56): well, this is the lot: http://iana.org/protocols/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:57): 7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7: yes i would think it is reasonable not to apply http limits to websocket
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:57): that's probably the default, too, since http != websocket :-)
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:58): yes, agreed, although it probably ought to be specified explicitly to make sure browser vendors keep them separate
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (19:58): yeah maybe
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (19:59): Server-sent events would also benefit from being kept separate from regular HTTP connections
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (20:01): in fact, it is probably reasonable to place a combined limit on SSE and WebSocket connections, separate from the limit on regular HTTP connections
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (20:01): I'm guessing webservice is TCP, right?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:01): wow, my filters totally caught the entire <q> thread and considered it low-priority
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (20:01): s/service/socket/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:01): my filters rock
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (20:02): so you don't need to register a protocol number

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:02): cool, 7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 sent some early feedback while I was eating a kebab: http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2008-October/016915.html
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (20:03): that appears to be the whole list then
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (20:03): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: but my feedback isn't nearly as tasty

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, since IE8 will be shipping soon with an implementation of <q> which matches HTML4 but differs from HTML5, maybe it should get bumped up the queue?
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:03): (for some definition of "soon")
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:04): i don't see what we can do but drop the entire element at this point
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:04): I suggest renaming the element from <q> to "
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:04): right
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:05): in my research, authors commonly use punctuation instead of <q> even when they do "
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:05): but they also use <em> with punctuation to avoid using <q> with CSS

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:07): so authors are happy to type the punctuation, but sometimes want styling as well...so if <q> was consistent with other phrase-level elements and didn't generate punctuation, that would be neat way of achieving this

74a4328c745033d9e822b77f22f3e272 (20:11): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: so another offline nit... should a resource that matched a fallback namespace, but didn't actually fallback, be considered "loaded from the application cache" for the purposes of the cache selection algorithm?
74a4328c745033d9e822b77f22f3e272 (20:11): it seems like it should, but it's not explicit.

7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (20:13): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: since there is no explicit limit set on WebSocket connections in the spec, does that imply there is no limit, so any number of WebSocket connections could be made from the same browser to the same WebSocket server?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:15): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: well apparently <q> generates punctuation
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (20:16): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: i did not understand kristof's reply to me :/
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:17): 7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45: nobody understands kristof really
7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7 (20:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: ok, do you have any objection to making that implication explicit in the spec?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:19): 7b9920d3e896b22057673a1c887015a7: not particularily, send feedback. :[)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:19): er
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:23): thanks
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I'd like to see your filters, they must have some serious intention-detecting voodoo going on

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:25): I feel sorry for Chris Wilson...his opening message is an implementor giving feedback during their final approach to shipping a product and there's very little he can take away from the thread which resulted

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:27): once all 4 main browsers are generating " on <q> and </q>, I guess we're stuck with it...even though hardly anyone uses <q> and it is impossible to internationise if it generates punctutation (as David Baron explained during the HTMLWG meeting)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:27): s/punctutation/punctuation/
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:28): s/internationise/internationalise/

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:29): b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f: They shouldn't need much voodoo - they can be based simply on the existing distributed socially-networked human-powered filtering system, i.e. if certain people choose to respond to a topic then you probably don't want to read it

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (20:31): Those people do all the hard work of reading the emails and classifying them into "I must give my opinion here!" and "this is just technical details, I don't care about this", so it's classified along the same boundaries that you want
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:33): I imagine that filtering any threads which generate so much noise from so few people would work quite well too
